title: Page example
text:
Sub-Section (Level #2)

Our Plot! (Level #3)
The plot may feel stretched. If this is the case, you will want to determine good plot-saving settings for a website.
For example, controlling the plot saving parameter argument of ggplot::sggsave() using units = "px" (pixels) and specifying the width (in pixels) and height (in pixels) may be a good approach. You can determine what pixel dimensions would be good for a webpage by doing and Internet search.
Example:

width    = 1600
height   = 1100
units    = "px"
dpi      = 200 # or "retina"

Our Plot with width configurations and no caption

title: Unemployment acorss different educational background sub-group
text:
Another variable examined in this project is educational background, represented by the peeduca variable, which captures the highest level of education attained by each respondent in the CPS dataset. Education is a key determinant in labor market outcomes, influencing employment opportunities, earnings potential, and overall career mobility.For this reason, we analyze how unemployment rates vary across educational backgrounds during the COVID-19 pandemic and the subsequent recovery period.

a descriptive graph with overall details (Tanveer’s graph)


a graph display variable acorss different years


some explanation behind - lit review

title: Analyzing the Impact of COVID-19 on United States Veteran Unemployment
section: Header Level 2: Tips for linking/displaying figures and images.
text:
Header Level 2: Tips for linking/displaying figures and images.

Header Level 3: Linking to a Plot/Fig

Write you code to create your plot and save it. Save this script in src/figs. The source code does not need to be on the website.
Ensure that your plot is saved to figs/ by referencing the path with {here}.
At the top of the .qmd file for your page, add a code block that source()s the script that will generate the plot you wish displayed on that page.

For example:
source(here::here("figs", "point_mpg_by_wt.png"))` 
Make sure to edit the code block so that the code runs only (no output).
NOTE: Code blocks that appear in .qmd files will call .R files only. Do NOT embed code blocks in your .qmd file(s) that will process data or create plots directly. Reserve .qmd files for website text, sourcing script files, and calling .png plot files. Developers and engineers compartmentalize project elements and do not combine all content into a single files. Doing so creates many problems not limited to code breaking and code-repair problems, Git merge problems, etc. You will follow a similar practice of breaking the project into pieces, save those files, and push them to the remote repository weekly for your team members.
This code-source()ing step also ensures that plot(s) are (re)created when Quarto rendering the website build files. You certainly want this feature so that new website elements and files are built during the rendering process. A full website re-build, however, is unnecessary when no element of the website changes other than the images and figures embedded within it. As a result, re-builds are not always necessary and will increase update time.

title: Analyzing the Impact of COVID-19 on United States Veteran Unemployment
section: Header Level 2: (Optional) Circumventing a Full Website Build
text:
Header Level 2: (Optional) Circumventing a Full Website Build
Sometimes the main structure of your website is untouched but you have new data and you need to run a rebuild of your plots. Although re-rendering is not problematic, it might just take longer than you desire. If you don’t need to render the website and just want to build files, the following is a solution, though requires some extra work.
To avoid a full site rebuild (re-render) when you simply want to create and git push new plots:

Add your source()ing code to a separate file, for example, call_scripts/call_plot_scripts.qmd.
Add a code block to source individual .R files or all .R files in a directory.

Example:
#| include: false

# source a script file that this page depends on
source(here::here("figs", "point_mpg_by_wt.R"))

This .qmd file will render and create the .png files you need in your specified directory but the page will not be linked on your website. Technically, it will be visible at https://the_url/call_scripts/call_plot_scripts.html but this will be difficult to find. You can always remove the file or directory after rendering the website if you want to remove it completely.


Link the plot .png file in your .qmd file.

Once you know the name and location of the file, you can reference it like this, where the .png file is being pulled from figs/:



a plot description



Linking to Image Example
Similarly, save your image in a folder like images/, and use this format to show it:



short description if necessary

title: Welcome to Data Viz CPS Team Website!
text:
About Our Project
We are looking at the different labor market patterns during the Covid-19 time using the CPS dataset. Our primary focus is on impact of COVID-19 on United States Veteran Unemployment, but we are also exmaining additional intersectionality such as household type, educational background and other demographic information.

title: Welcome to Data Viz CPS Team Website!
text:
U.S. Government Current Population Survey (CPS)
Current Population Survey, commonly referred to as the CPS, is conducted jointly by two major U.S. government agencies, the U.S. Census Bureau and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, or BLS.
The CPS is a monthly household survey designed to measure key aspects of the labor market and demographic information.
For each month, it collects data from around 60,000 households, representing millions of individuals nationwide. The dataset covers a wide range of variables as well, including employment and unemployment status, income, educational background, household structures, and other demographic characteristics. Because of this rich demographic variables, the CPS is one of the few datasets that allow researchers to examine not only broad labor market trends, but also the distributional impacts on different diverse groups.
It has also maintained a consistent survey design since the 1940s, which allows researchers to make meaningful comparisons over time and track how labor markets respond to major events and economic recession for example Covid-19 which is the main focus of our group

title: Welcome to Data Viz CPS Team Website!
text:
Our Data Analysis Focus
Our project focuses on understanding the impact of major events on unemployment recovery, with an emphasis on identifying who recovered and why. The analysis seeks to capture how factors such as economic resilience, social structure, and individual resources shaped different recovery experiences.

Covid-19 Pandemic
The analysis centers on the Covid-19 pandemic period and the subsequent recovery phase, capturing how unemployment trends evolved as the economy reopened. This timeline allows for comparison between the height of pandemic-related job losses and the gradual return to employment, providing insights into long-term recovery and disparities that persisted beyond the immediate crisis.


Variables
Overall CPS variables dictionary
The Current population survey household data contains a wide range of variables, and to further explore these dynamics, several key variables from the data were selected:

ptdtrace – Race
peeduca – Highest Education Background
prtgage – Age
pelaydur – Unemployment Duration (in weeks)
hrhtype – Household Type
peafever – Veteran Status

These variables together capture demographic, socioeconomic, and structural characteristics that influence how individuals and communities experienced unemployment recovery during and after the pandemic.

title: Meet The Team
text:
We are the Data Visualization CPS Project Team, responsible for analyzing and visualizing CPS data for our Data Visualization class. Our goal is to turn complex datasets into clear, engaging visuals that effectively communicate key insights and patterns to our audience.

title: Jessica Lin HW8
text:
You will ensure that your data and plotting scripts needed for creating your plot are used to build the up-to-date version of the plot.



# source data-related scripts 

# source plotting script(s)
source(here::here("src", "figs", "plotting.R"))




Describe why you might want to implement this approach.
First is the x-axis label, now it’s all 4 digits which is the correct way of indicating the year. I added one segment label using the annotate() function to mark the threshold/margin in the BLS system to differentiate short-term and long-term unemployed time and it was 15 weeks. So by this, we can shift the audience’s focus back onto how the covid pandamic was influencing the unemployment patterns as 2020 and 2021 was the only two years that had almost every racial group’s mean unemployment time over the long-term mark.




# plot with a caption

#| fig.cap: "Mean Unemployment Time by different racial groups"
#| fig.align: "center" # to center plot on page if desired
#| out.width: "100%"   # or some other % appropriate for you site

knitr::include_graphics(here::here("figs", "mean_race_unemploy.png"))

title: Key Directories
text: Building a website requires management of relevatn files, which you must keep our files organized and easily accessible. A well-structured directory helps us to collaborate efficiently, reduce errors, and facilitate project maintenance. Let’s explore the purpose of each file or directory.

title: Key Directories
text:
Project Directory Structure
.
├── .git
├── .gitignore
├── .nojekyll
├── .quarto
├── about.qmd
├── blog/
│   ├── _metadata.yml
│   ├── index.qmd
│   └── posts/
├── figs/
├── fonts/
│   └── fontawesome.html
├── images/
│   ├── icons/
│   ├── random_png.png
│   └── profile.jpg
├── index.qmd
├── pages/
│   ├── my_first_page.qmd
│   └── my_second_page.qmd
├── prerender.R  <-------------------------------------------------
├── <projectname>.Rproj
├── robots.txt
└── src/
    ├── data/
    ├── figs/
    ├── functions/
    │   ├── fig_saving.R
    │   ├── fig_theme.R
    │   ├── load_libraries.R
    │   └── view_html.R
    ├── starter_script_file.R
    └── utils/
        └── made-of-code.tmTheme
└── styles/

title: Key Directories
text:
Configuration Files
These configuration files are stored in the project root (.) directory:

.git: contains Git version control system files (do not delete)
.gitignore: specifies files and directories that Git should ignore (e.g, your .Renviron, .Rprofile, and other sensitive details) (do not delete)
.nojekyll: tells GitHub Pages not to use Jekyll to build the site
.quarto: for Quarto-specific configuration files.

title: Key Directories
text:
Website Files and Directories

about.qmd: a website about page (do not delete)
docs/: for all rendered website files
index.qmd: a website start page (do not delete)
pages/: for individual web pages 
robots.txt: This file specifies how search engines should crawl our site.
styles/: for website theme related files

title: Key Directories
text:
Source Code
The src/ directory contains our project source code:
src/
  data/
  figs/
  functions/
    fig_saving.R
    fig_theme.R
    load_libraries.R
    view_html.R
  starter_script_file.R
  utils/
    made-of-code.tmTheme

data/: for data, raw/ and processed/
figs/: for .png figures created with {ggplot2} code
functions/: reusable functions needed for the project
utils/: for project utility files

title: Key Directories
text:
Figures and Images
The following directories contain figures and image files:
figs/
images/
  icons/

figs/: for figures generated by code
images/: for image files
icons/: for icon files
random_png.png and profile.jpg: example files

title: Key Directories
text:
Brand Directory
brand/

brand/: for _brand.yml and related files

title: Key Directories
text:
Blog Directory
The blog directory contains files related to our project blog:
blog/
  _metadata.yml
  index.qmd
  posts/

title: Page example
text:
Quarto files are structured similar to R Markdown files. You can bold and italicize text, create hyperlinks, and also bullet items among other things. There is a lot you can do with Quarto for building, website.

Formatting
Use headers
Write formatted content
Displaying plots and images
Link to other websites
Link to other pages on this site

Write you code to create your plot and save it. Save this script in src/figs. The source code does not need to be on the website.

For example:
source(here::here("figs", "point_mpg_by_wt.R"))`
Make sure to edit the code block so that the code runs only (no output).
NOTE: Code blocks that appear in .qmd files will call .R files only. Do NOT embed code blocks in your .qmd file(s) that will process data or create plots directly. Reserve .qmd files for website text, sourcing script files, and calling .png plot files. Developers and engineers compartmentalize project elements and do not combine all content into a single files. Doing so creates many problems not limited to code breaking and code-repair problems, Git merge problems, etc. You will follow a similar practice of breaking the project into pieces, save those files, and push them to the remote repository weekly for your team members.
This code-source()ing step also ensures that plot(s) are (re)created when Quarto rendering the website build files. You certainly want this feature so that new website elements and files are built during the rendering process. A full website re-build, however, is unnecessary when no element of the website changes other than the images and figures embedded within it. As a result, re-builds are not always necessary and will increase update time.

title: Site Name
text:
Welcome to Site Name! Blah, blah…


This simple site serves as the core template for building your website and is designed to communicate elements of building your plots, pages, and content for a webpage. You will build a Quarto website for a target audience to communicate data visualized in ways to communicate patterns, trends, in data or to tell a story about data. There are more advanced styling you can modify with Quarto websites but this template is a good starting point if you are unfamiliary with Quarto.






Exploratory Data Stories

Purpose: Allows visitors to interact with data to explore patterns and relationships.
Some Characteristic:

Guided narrative plus visualizations

User-driven discovery (obviates raw data analysis skills)


Demonstrates that you can you can clean and wrangle raw open data, but also combine storytelling and data interpretation.

Analytical Decision-Support Tools

Purpose: Help professionals understand data and make informed choices.
Some Characteristic:

Multiple data metrics
Provides different slices/groupings of data

Demonstrates that you can clean and wrangle raw open data and can work with complex data sets that support business decisions directly.

Public Transparency & Open Data Portals

Purpose: Share government or research data in a user-friendly way for either accountability or public engagement or both.
Some Characteristics:

Clear, accessible visuals for non-expert audiences

Open data downloads

Trend and comparison features

Demonstrates you can clean and wrangle raw open data, combine multiple data sources, and provide value to otherwise stagnant data.









Save files in random places (see directory structure)
Hard-code paths (e.g., /myusername/directory/subdirectory/file.R or C:/myusername/directory/subdirectory/file.R)
Import or process data without code
Save/export plot files without code
Use the R Studio Git GUI
Use spaces for directory names or file names
use UPPERCASE characters in directories and file names





Save files in a directory structure
Reference directory and file paths using the {here} library

by importing files using code
by saving/exporting files using code

Use Git commands in the RStudio terminal
Use machine-readable file paths (e.g., directory and file names)

by replacing spaces with _ or - (choose one)
by making all characters lowercase








Develop Website Content

Modify a _quarto.yml (YAML) config file for the page structure, options, and configuration
Structure Quarto .qmd input files for the website pages (e.g., index.qmd, about.qmd, etc.)
Add text content for the input file pages
Render website files using Build > Render Website or {quarto} library; See here for more details
Push to GitHub and manage in GitHub Pages

Maintain File Organization

Organize directories and files
Maintain a directory structure

Create Data File(s) and Scripts

Save data files in appropriate directory in data/ (e.g., data/raw/)
Write .R scripts for cleaning and summarizing data using {tidyverse} libraries
Save data-related scripts in src/data/ using meaningful and standardized names
Save cleaned/processed data files data/processed/

Create Plot Scripts, Functions, and Files

Scripts

Write .R scripts for creating plots using {ggplot}
Save plot-related scripts in src/figs/ using meaningful and standardized names

Function Script(s)

Write a function to ensure uniform saving of plots using ggplot2::ggsave() and save function in src/figs/ so that you can apply it systematically to format plot objects

Plot Files

Save plots/figures as .png files in figs/ making sure to use unique names for each plot
Link .png files inside webpages so they load

(Optional) Customize a Website Theme

Create a custom.scss Sass file to manage color schemes and save in styles/ or create a _brand.yml file
Additional theme tips can be found here








ggplot2 Reference
Tips for website pages Other
Quarto Documentation
Quarto Websites
Theming with a _brand.yml, example here
More on Brand YML
Other Theming

title: Unemployment acorss different racial sub-group
text:
Overview
Text here …

source(here::here("src", "figs", "plotting.R")) 

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'race'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
